Practical Placeholders

Source: vignettes/practical.Rmd
practical.Rmd
library(lipsum)

Customisable Lorem Ipsum: Loripsum

The loripsum() function is probably the best go-to place holder text API in the package, and provides the most control over the output as far as contents are concerned.

example_loripsum <-
  loripsum(
    n = 3L,
    length = "short",
    decorate = TRUE, # adds italics, bold, etc.
    link = TRUE, # adds some links
    ul = TRUE, # adds an unordered list (bullets)
    ol = TRUE, # adds an ordererd list (numbers)
    dl = TRUE, # adds a description list (headers and contents)
    bq = TRUE, # adds a blockquote
    code = TRUE, # adds code samples
    headers = FALSE, # adds headers - may mess with RMarkdown/Quarto!
    allcaps = FALSE, # capitalises the whole output
    prude = TRUE # see above note
  )
View Output

Markdown-formatted: Lorem Markdownum

The Lorem Markdownum API is similar to the Loripsum API in terms of giving a lot of control over the output, but outputs the place holder text using markdown formatting.

example_markdown <-
  lipsum::markdownum(
    n = 10L,
    # drop various elements?
    no_headers = TRUE,
    no_code = FALSE,
    no_inline_markup = FALSE,
    no_quotes = FALSE,
    no_lists = FALSE,
    no_external_links = FALSE,
    no_wrapping = FALSE,
    # change formatting?
    underline_headers = TRUE,
    reference_links = TRUE,
    underscore_em = TRUE,
    underscore_strong = TRUE,
    fenced_code_blocks = TRUE
  )
View Output

Random Corporate Articles: CorporateLorem

CorporateLorem is very different from Loripsum in that users get exceedingly little control over the output. In fact, the only control one truly gets is the number of paragraphs returned. However, unlike other lorem ipsum generators, the user receives actual English prose from a variety of topics. This output may be a bit less distracting to colleagues/clients compared to random Latin phrases.

example_corporate <-
  lipsum::corporatelorem(n = 3L)
View Output Technology

Alphabet’s stock rose 3.5 percent in after-hours trading, and some analysts recommended the company’s shares. With the regulatory issue settled, they said, Google could get back to focusing on selling ads across the internet.”It’s like a delivery company having to pay for a parking ticket,” Brian Wieser, a Pivotal Research analyst, said of the penalty, which Alphabet accounted for in the second quarter. “It’s not a meaningful fine in the context of the size of this company.”

Wearing face masks that adequately cover the mouth and nose causes the error rate of some of the most widely used facial recognition algorithms to spike to between 5 percent and 50 percent, a study by the US National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has found. Black masks were more likely to cause errors than blue masks, and the more of the nose covered by the mask, the harder the algorithms found it to identify the face.

As that weirdo, Google’s design makes perfect sense and it’s possible it might do the same for regular folk. The new layout for search result is ugly at first glance — but then Google was always ugly until relatively recently. I very quickly learned to unconsciously take in the information from the top favicon and URL-esque info without it really distracting me. …Which is basically the problem. Google’s using that same design language to identify its ads instead of much more obvious, visually distinct methods. It’s consistent, I guess, but it also feels deceptive.
